data.q: What is authentication in a web application?
o: Verifying the identity of a user
data.e: Authentication is the process of verifying who the user is, typically using credentials like username and password.

o: Determining what actions a user can perform
data.e: Authorization decides what an authenticated user is allowed to access or perform.

data.q: Which Flask extension is commonly used for user authentication?
data.e: Flask-Login provides session management, login, logout, and user handling utilities.

data.q: What is a session in a web application?
o: Temporary data stored between HTTP requests
data.e: Sessions store user-specific data across multiple HTTP requests, since HTTP itself is stateless.

data.q: Where are session identifiers typically stored on the client?
data.e: Session IDs are usually stored in cookies and sent automatically with each request.

data.q: Which HTTP method is most appropriate for a login form submission?
data.e: POST is preferred because it sends credentials in the request body rather than the URL.

data.q: Why should passwords never be stored in plain text?
o: They can be easily compromised if leaked
data.e: Storing passwords in plain text is insecure; hashing protects users even if the database is compromised.

data.q: Which function is commonly used to hash passwords in Python web apps?
data.e: bcrypt provides a secure, salted hashing mechanism suitable for passwords.

data.q: What is the purpose of CSRF protection?
o: Prevent unauthorized actions from authenticated users
data.e: CSRF protection ensures that requests come from trusted sources and not from malicious third-party sites.

data.q: What happens when a user logs out of a session-based application?
o: The session data is invalidated or destroyed
data.e: Logging out invalidates the session so it can no longer be used for authenticated access.
